text:
This is Mark Wiens with eating Thai food dot
com and today I'm going to make a recipe for

gaeng keow wan gai, which is green curry with
chicken, and magic of this dish lies within

the kung gang, which is the curry paste, this
big blob of green stuff, that's the stuff

we're looking for today and this is the flavor
that will give us the deliciousness of the
green curry we're about to cook.
Let's go over the ingredients real fast.

You'll need about a quarter of a chicken chopped
up, or if you want, two chicken breasts will
work fine as well.

You'll need twelve Thai round eggplants, five
non-hot spur chillies, three to four stems

of Thai sweet basil, six to eight kaffir lime
leaves, around six cups of coconut milk, I'll

be using fresh but you can easily buy it in
a can, four heaping tablespoons of thai green

curry paste, since I'm in Thailand I'll be
using fresh curry paste, but you can easily
find it in a bottle or package.

You'll also need about a half a tablespoon
of fermented shrimp paste which is also available

in a can, two teaspoons of sugar and one teaspoon
of salt.

The first thing you need to do in cut the
chicken.

If you're using a chicken leg, you'll have
to chop it with a big knife, but if you're

using chicken breasts, you'll just need to
slice them up into the bite sized pieces.

Wash all twelve of the eggplants and cut them
into quarters.

Add all your ingredients to a plate, but keep
them separate as you'll be adding them at
different times.
Then chop the five spur chillies into slivers.

The next step is to pluck all the leaves off
three to four stems of Thai sweet basil and
put them aside.

Roughly cut six to eight kaffir lime leaves,
you can even just crumple up them with your
hands.

Start by pouring five cups of coconut milk
into a medium sized pot and put it on medium
heat.

When the coconut milk is still heating up,
stir in around four tablespoons of Thai green
curry paste.

Make sure it all dissolves into the coconut
milk.

Then stir in half of a tablespoon of fermented
shrimp paste.
Allow the mixture to get very hot.

But just before it comes to a boil add the
eight kaffir lime leaves and then put in all
the chopped pieces of chicken.

Be sure to put them in carefully so they don't
splash all over the place.

Stir the curry for a few seconds and then
just let it sit for about three minutes until
it comes to a rolling boil.

After the curry boils, give it a quick stir
and then leave it again for one more minute.

Then you need to add all the eggplant to the
curry.
Stir it for about thirty seconds.

If the curry becomes too thick, add another
half to full cup of coconut milk.

You want the consistency to be somewhere in-between
a watery soup and a gravy.

After stirring it up, add two teaspoons of
sugar followed by one teaspoon of salt.

This is also the time to taste the curry and
see if it needs any more curry paste for flavor
or salt.

If the flavor is not strong enough, go ahead
and add another spoon of green curry paste.

Make sure the green curry is well mixed and
then boil it for about five minutes while
occasionally giving it a quick stir.

The final step is to add the sliced spur chillies
and the sweet basil into the curry and immediately
turn off the heat.

The existing heat from the coconut milk will
cook the sweet basil long enough so it still
remains fragrant.

Give the curry a quick stir and it's ready
to be served.

Like most Thai curries, make sure you eat
this Thai green chicken curry with a plate
of rice!
